titleStmt.title: Gertrude Bugler to Mrs Hardy — Declining the role of “Tess”, 4 February 1925

publicationStmt.p: Unpublished autograph letter held at the Dorset History Centre / Dorset Museum, MS H.1542.

support.p: Small bifolium of pale grey wove paper; written recto of first two pages in black ink; remaining sides blank. Light rust stain at inner margin; deckled edges.

layout.p: Single column of continuous lines; generous left margin; closer and signature at foot of p.2.

handNote.p: Right-slanting cursive hand with open loops and frequent long descenders; occasional overwriting and struck-out corrections; firm black ink.

msDesc.note: Pencilled shelfmark “H.1542” at head of p.2 by later archival hand.

abstract.p: Writing from Beaminster, Gertrude Bugler informs Mrs Hardy that she has told Mr Harrison she cannot play Tess, explaining she will not part from her child Diana and that her husband is unhappy about the plan; she adds that Miss Thorndike may produce the play later with greater success.

note.p: Gertrude Bugler (1900–1997) was a Dorset actor closely associated with stage versions of Tess of the d’Urbervilles. This note to Mrs Hardy (Florence Emily Hardy) concerns a proposed production, referencing “Mr Harrison” (likely a theatrical manager) and “Miss Thorndike,” indicating that another celebrated actress might undertake the role.

div.p:
I think I ought to tell you that I have written to Mr Harrison to tell him that I cannot play “Tess” after all!
I cannot part with Diana and my husband is not very happy about it all and I have no right to sacrifice their happiness.

I do not think Mr Harrison will mind very much, for he probably knows that— Miss Thorndike is likely to produce the play later and that with her reputation it will be a greater success.
In a way, I am sorry, but I think it will be for the best.
